description:

subwindow is too small (although it stretches as you type). The info you
type gets truncated at the right end of the window. The app is pretty good
otherwise.
summary: The ability to review applications is kludgey

description: Does a better job of finding updates and new software then the built in store app. on Fedora 36.
summary: LOVE IT. Try it and see for yourself

description: I just think that Discover could be so much better. It works well for just updating your apps and system packages, and to install an application you know by name, but fails at everything else. here are my nitpicks: the home page should show most popular apps first, then the "featured", and then the "recently published/updated" (the "Discover" part of the program!); the installed should have four subsections: installed applications, installed application addons, installed plasma addons, and installed system packages. It's extremely confusing to see everything at once; The store page of an app should show whether it's a verified distributor and/or if it's a system app; and in general this app could really use a UX/UI rework... If you're not familiar with the app it's very unintuitive - the search is on the top left, barely visible, the install and remove buttons are also on the top right, they're really small, also why are the categories always shown, if you select the games category why isn't something like heroic or steam not the first things you see... Sorry for the rant, but Discover just could be so much bettter. I think it has great potential, and I really hope that it will be great.
while the ui is bad but at least it doesnt crash or isnt spinning all the time

It's a nice idea and it is useful to see the (small) screenshots and descriptions of the software but man it crashes out a lot. If I already know the name of the software I'm looking for then I use apt instead. It would be great to have a reliable stable version, especially to encourage new users to linux.
Not bad and more better from Fedora Software Center but the repo is error after install on Fedora 24 update.
It really sucks!
Discover is really buggy, the design is really bad, to say the least.

i like it. i would love it, but i experience some strange behavior.
Sometimes (most of the time) it always check for updates. some of the apps (and these are a lot) i cannot install because if missing dependencies (but this might not be related to discover...im a novice, not a power user, and my system is pretty much stock with some apps installed from terminal that i use)
i mean it helped a little but like i said its good for what it is
summary: kinda good for what it is

description: Great if you like scrolling ALL DAY LONG. Nothing is made easy or itemized. You want to find something in your system? Scroll for it. Maybe you will get it after FOREVER. You want to find a new program, scroll for it. This really sucks.

'Discover' can a big help if you need some orientation. The problem is, you can't get more of it. After all, it remains chaos, attractively displayed in endless lists, filtered by intransparent manufacturer-made settings.
Recently that is.
From a wonky debut, to a proper app center. Still asking for more love.

Discover does have its advantages, primarily for browsing through lists of available software when you don't exactly know what it is you're looking for. If anything, because of that, Discover is useful and unique. It's got screenshots, it's got reviews, and it's got a pleasant, friendly presentation.

What else is Discover? It's annoying as all Hell, because it's far from finished--and poorly designed. The search facility can barely function intelligently and filter anything out (still looking!), keyboard shortcuts are hardly implemented (and the ones that are behave VERY strangely), and the "Remove" buttons are agonizingly too close to the scroll bar (oops!). It can't even remember a preferred window size. In spite of its pleasant, friendly presentation, I actually am reluctant to use it.

It's useful to have Apper (KDE), Muon Package Manager (KDE), or Synaptic Package Manager installed, alongside Discover, so that you can have more precision when you want it.
summary: Nice Idea, but Still Not Ready for Prime Time

description: requires me to still open the console to do anything. might aswell just delete this and do it the old fashioned way. :-(

As seems to be the case with everything tech and software related, I relentlessly am reminded of the absolute disgrace that the current state of affairs is in, by once again having a shiny carrot dangled in front of me, only to find that it is rotten to the core. It is laughable the fact that even the simplest of tasks is screwed up in a monumental fashion leaving me once again to undo what has been done and then to reinvent the wheel all over again in order to get the original task completed in the first place. :-(

description: I've had no problems with it on Kubuntu.

This program is very nicely layed out, well behaved, and even stable. And yet, I find it difficult to use at times.
In order of discovery, not importnce, here are the issues I have found worth mentioning.

1. Following the desktop manager theme is inconsistent. With some KDE themes, it will switch from black letters on 
blinding white background to white text on appropriate gray.
Under the management of other themes, it stays white. Why is this important? Some of us have delicate eyes and 
choose not to wear sunglasses indoors at midnight. The white background makes it difficult to read the screen.

2. Components Placement. At times, the menus will be on the left. At other times, the whole main screen will flip and
 be arrangenged right to left. I have no problem with a screen flowing RTL, but this is typically the domain of
languages that are written RTL. Besides, why flip? I cnnot tell. It just does.

3. If you wonder why some lines in this review are erratically short, it has to do with the wiget used to enter
the review. First, it tries to dynamically adjust its size bsed on the text entered. It does, but in a bit strange way.
Words get swollowed on the far right and the window may or may not grow to expose them. If this feature was 
imlemented correctly, it would have been just uncomfortanle - 
a person likes to know where the end of the page is.

4. Finally, the font used by this application is very, very small. On my 13" laptop (96DPI), the default font is a
uncomfortable 12 points.
With this application, this translate to a 1.5mm "tall" letters. With my eyes, this minute text is almost invisible.
 I have to pick up the PC and hold it under my nose to see what I am rambling about.
It should be a bit bigger.

Other than these knits I picked, the program is really very good, and I use it daily with excellent reults.
WHEN I TRY DOWNLOADING AN APP DISCOVER OPENS,WHY?,I HAVE NO IDEA
it shows no application and searching sign is just moves all the and shows nothing

description:
Glitches in basic features! Needs work
before it is actually ready for release.

It ships with kubuntu; it's handy to search trough kde.store but when dealing with updates it's freezes; sometimes freezes the system; would be better to have it only firing an alert and don'r start the process of updating and leaving the updating to the user via the terminal! It interferes with the work oe's doing and that's a bad behaviour! It needs UX improvement !

This package manager has so many annoying quirks that it's does not matter if you list them because the developers just don't pay attention to the users.

But, how about better integration with at least one of the new packaging technologies such as Flatpaks, Snaps, AppImage.
How about laying the apps icons horizontally for better viewing as Gnome-Software package manager does. It seems that that is a more logical way to navigate without damaging your eyesight.
KDE Plasma deserves better. It is time to update its software management front end.

If you are using KDE Plasma, you should have Synaptic or/and Gnome-Software managers installed if you want easier more precise package installations or viewing. Maybe I am asking for too much here.
summary: Feels outdated and KDE users are stuck with it

Con las últimas actualizaciones esta casi perfecto.
Cosas que se aprecian que han llegado:
- Ahora indica cuando instala de snap, flatpack o algún repo.
- Mejoras en el filtro
- Puede mostrar la descripción e info adicional de la app sin necesidad de salir del listado de aplicaciones
- Muestra tamaño de paquetes
- Muestra versión a instalar
- Muestra origen
- Estabilidad

Cosas que faltan:
- Falta una opcion de detalles que indique el listado dependencias
- Falta que diga el nombre del paquete para poder instalarlo manualmente si quiero
- Arreglar las animaciones de carga (NVidia + X11)
